articles.headline: G.O.P. Blocks Debate on Financial Oversight Bill
articles.snippet: Democrats fell short of the 60 votes needed to cut off a filibuster as Republicans united in opposition to the bill to tighten regulation of the financial system.
articles.abstract: Democrats fell short of the 60 votes needed to cut off a filibuster as Republicans united in opposition to the bill to tighten regulation of the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans, united in opposition to the Democrats’ legislation to tighten regulation of the financial system, voted on Monday to block the bill from reaching the floor for debate. As both sides dug in, the battle has huge ramifications for the economy and for their political prospects in this year’s midterm elections.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: Cape Cod Project Is Crucial Step for U.S. Wind Industry
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s decision on a Cape Cod wind project will have implications from Long Island to Lake Erie.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s decision on a Cape Cod wind project will have implications from Long Island to Lake Erie.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 800 giant wind turbines spin off the coasts of Denmark, Britain and seven other European countries, generating enough electricity from strong ocean breezes to power hundreds of thousands of homes. China’s first offshore wind farm, a 102-megawatt venture near Shanghai, goes online this month, with more in the pipeline.

articles.headline:
Mortgage Deals
Under Scrutiny as Goldman Faces Senators
articles.snippet: The legal storm buffeting Goldman Sachs continued to rage Tuesday just ahead of what is expected to be a contentious Senate hearing into its actions during the housing crisis.
articles.abstract: The legal storm buffeting Goldman Sachs continued to rage Tuesday just ahead of what is expected to be a contentious Senate hearing into its actions during the housing crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The legal storm buffeting Goldman Sachs continued to rage Tuesday just ahead of what is expected to be a contentious Senate hearing at which bank executives plan to defend their actions during the housing crisis.

articles.headline: Russian Adoptees Get a Respite on the Range
articles.snippet: Many Russian adoptees, whose abuse began before they were born, have found healing grace at a Montana ranch.
articles.abstract: Many Russian adoptees, whose abuse began before they were born, have found healing grace at a Montana ranch.
articles.lead_paragraph: EUREKA, Mont. — Hundreds of adopted children, most of them Russian, have come here to northwest Montana to live and perhaps find healing grace with the horses and cows and rolling fields on Joyce Sterkel’s ranch. Some want to return to the families that adopted them, despite their troubles.

articles.headline: Home Tax Credit Called Successful, but Costly
articles.snippet: Analysts say most of the $12.6 billion in credits were collected by those who would have bought homes anyway.
articles.abstract: Analysts say most of the $12.6 billion in credits were collected by those who would have bought homes anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: Realtors, home buyers and sellers are rushing to complete sales agreements before the tax credit for home purchases expires this week.

articles.headline: We Have Met the Enemy and He Is PowerPoint
articles.snippet: PowerPoint has crept into the daily lives of U.S. military commanders and reached the level of near obsession.
articles.abstract: PowerPoint has crept into the daily lives of U.S. military commanders and reached the level of near obsession.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the leader of American and NATO forces in Afghanistan, was shown a PowerPoint slide in Kabul last summer that was meant to portray the complexity of American military strategy, but looked more like a bowl of spaghetti.

articles.headline: Off Wall St., Worries About Financial Bill
articles.snippet: More than 130 companies have retained lobbyists to weigh in on the debate over financial regulation.
articles.abstract: More than 130 companies have retained lobbyists to weigh in on the debate over financial regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mars, the maker of M&M’s and Snickers, wants to make sure it can continue dabbling in the derivatives market to protect the price of sugar and chocolate for its candies.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: A Crowd With Pity for Goldman
articles.snippet: At a financial industry conference, many of the attendees seemed to believe that Goldman Sachs had done nothing wrong in helping clients place bets that the housing bubble was going to burst.
articles.abstract: At a financial industry conference, many of the attendees seemed to believe that Goldman Sachs had done nothing wrong in helping clients place bets that the housing bubble was going to burst.

articles.headline: Confidence About Greek Debt Falters in Germany
articles.snippet: Fears are increasing that even with money that is promised, Greece will have to restructure its debts, leaving investors booking losses.
articles.abstract: Fears are increasing that even with money that is promised, Greece will have to restructure its debts, leaving investors booking losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Confidence in Greek assets sank to a new low on Monday, as Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany kept up the pressure on Greece, insisting on tougher austerity measures.
articles.byline: By Judy Dempsey and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: Panel’s Blunt Questions Put Goldman on Defensive
articles.snippet: The gap between Wall Street and the rest of the country was a recurring theme at Tuesday’s subcommittee hearing.
articles.abstract: The gap between Wall Street and the rest of the country was a recurring theme at Tuesday’s subcommittee hearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before the first question was leveled inside the Senate chamber, Tuesday was going to be uncomfortable for Goldman Sachs.
